tasks.name: Task #3

steps.title: Wristband with biosensor
steps.text:
We would like to know what it was like for you to wear the wristband.

Please read each statement and chose the option that best describes how you feel.

steps.title: I like how the wristband looks.
The wristband looks too big.
I was embarrassed to wear the wristband.
The wristband looks cool.
The wristband attracted too much attention.
The wristband was comfortable.
The wristband fit well around my wrist.
The wristband was easy to use.
The wristband was easy to charge.
I often forgot to wear the wristband.
I wanted to wear the wristband.
It was irritating to push the button on the wristband.
I remembered to push the button on the wristband every time OCD was bothering me.
Is there anything else you would like to tell us about your experience wearing the wristband?
You are done!
steps.text: Thank you for telling us what you think about the wristband. Your answers will help us make the wristband better

tasks.title: Wristband with biosensor
tasks.description: We would like to know what it was like for you to wear the wristband.

tasks.name: Task #4

steps.title: Exposure and response prevention
steps.text:
This survey is designed to help you practice fighting OCD. To take back control from OCD, you must do the opposite of what OCD wants you to do. For example, you may touch some food left over on your plate or say some “dangerous” words. Or, if the OCD tells you to touch things a certain number of times, don't do it. Going against OCD can be scary or upsetting. But, to take control back from OCD, you can’t run away from the discomfort or fear - you must tough it out.

During the exercise, notice what happens to the feeling of discomfort for up to 15 minutes.

While you practice going against OCD, your parents or your therapist can help you use this form.

steps.title: What do you think is going to happen to your feelings of discomfort, fear or disgust when you practice doing the opposite of what OCD wants you to do?

choices.text: My discomfort/fear/disgust will grow and grow until I can't take it any more
I will feel less discomfort/fear/disgust over time

steps.text:
Many children and adolescents think that their fear or discomfort will get worse and worse when they practice going against OCD, but that is not what happens.

For many children and adolescents, the fear/discomfort goes up and down during the exercise. For some people, the fear/discomfort becomes less during the exercise. Others find that their fear/discomfort does not really change during the exercise, but then they learn that fear and discomfort are not dangerous. With lots of practice, you should really notice that you feel less fear, disgust or discomfort.

steps.title:
Before you start practicing going against OCD, prepare for the exercise by answering some questions.

You're going to do something difficult and that should be rewarded. How will you reward yourself after the exercise of fighting OCD?

choices.text: Watch an episode of your favorite series
Do something fun with friends/ family (make a plan)
I will do something not listed here

steps.title:
In the exercise, I will work on an obsession.

(Obsessions are unwanted thoughts or images that keep popping into your head and that you can't stop thinking about, even though you want to be rid of them.)
The obsession I want to work on now is about:

choices.text: Fear/ disgust of pollution, infection, dirt, bacteria, diseases
Fear of harming myself or others (physically or emotionally)
Disturbing thoughts/ images about sex, pregnancy or sexuality
Need to collect things or fear of losing something
Magical/superstitious thoughts or actions (e.g. lucky numbers or words; stepping on a crack can break someone’s back)
Worry about having a disease or that a body part or your appearance looks wrong)
Fear of offending God or Satan or worry about what is right and wrong
Symmetry and order (e.g. that things must lie in a certain way, or things must be in order)
Needing to do something until it feels right or not wrong

steps.title: You can describe the obsession you want to work on here, if you would like to describe it detail or if you could not find an obsession in the list.

I want to work with a compulsion.


(Compulsions are things that OCD wants you to do. If you try to resist doing these things or try not to do what OCD tells you to, you may feel afraid, worried, frustrated, angry or upset.)
The compulsion I will work on is about:

choices.text: Checking (like if you have remembered to lock the door)
Repeating actions (like turning the lights on and off several times)
Fixing things or trying to get things in a certain place or symmetrical
Collecting things or difficulty throwing things away
Magical/superstitious behavior (like doing or saying things a certain number of times to prevent something bad from happening)
Involving your parents in a ritual or asking for reassurance
Doing something until it feels right

steps.title: You can describe the compulsion you want to work on here, if you would like to describe it detail or if you could not find a compulsion in the list.
Describe how you will practice going against OCD. How do you want to work on the obsession and/or compulsion (for example touching the toilet seat or making your desk messy):

steps.text:
On the next pages, you will be asked to note how much fear or discomfort you experience while you go against OCD.

Start by noting how uncomfortable it is for you to think about doing the exercise you just described on a scale of 0 to 10. 0 means that you are completely calm or not at all afraid. 10 means that you are so scared or upset you can’t stand it.

steps.title: How much discomfort do you feel after 1 minute?
How much discomfort do you feel after 3 minutes?
How much discomfort do you feel after 5 minutes?
How much discomfort do you feel after 7 minutes?
How much discomfort do you feel after 10 minutes?
How much discomfort do you feel after 15 minutes?

Well done! You stayed with some difficult feelings!

What happened to those difficult feelings when you practiced doing the opposite of what OCD wants?

choices.text: My discomfort grew until I couldn’t stand it anymore
My discomfort went up and down
My discomfort did not really change
I felt less discomfort with time

steps.title: You are done with the exercise!
steps.text: Remember to give yourself that reward

tasks.title: Fight back against OCD
tasks.description: Describe the obsession and/or the compulsion you are working on

tasks.name: Task #5

measures.name: How are you feeling right now?

steps.title: Are you alone?

choices.text: I am with my mother/father who is also participating in the study
I am  with my other parent who is not participating in the study
I am with my sister(s) and/ or brother(s)
I am with others we have not mentioned

steps.title: We would like to know your current mood
steps.text:
Below are a list of different feelings and emotions.

Please read each feeling and choose the option that best matches how much you feel each feeling right now.

steps.title: Miserable

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Mad

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Lively

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Sad

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Joyful

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Scared

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Cheerful

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Happy

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Afraid

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Proud

choices.text: Very slightly or not at all

steps.title: Thank you for telling us how you feel
steps.text: By answering this survey you are helping us connect how you feel to your bodily signals

tasks.title: How are you feeling right now?
tasks.description: We would like to know your current mood

tasks.name: Task #6

steps.title: Obsessions
steps.text:
Symptom Hierarchy: Obsessions


Obsessions are unwanted thoughts or images that keep popping into your head and that you can't stop thinking about, even though you want to be rid of them.

On the next pages, you will see obsessions that many people with OCD have. Tell us how upset or scared each obsession has been for you over the past week by choosing the number that best matches how you feel. 0 means that you have not had the obsession or that it is not at all unpleasant and 10 means that the obsession is so upsetting you can’t stand it.

steps.title: Fear/ disgust of pollution, infection, dirt, bacteria, diseases
Fear of harming yourself or others (body or feelings)
Disturbing thoughts/ images about sex, pregnancy or sexuality
Need to collect things or fear of losing something
Magical/superstitious thoughts or actions (e.g. lucky numbers or words; stepping on a crack can break someone’s back)
Worry about having a disease or that a body part or your appearance looks wrong
Fear of offending God or Satan or worry about what is right and wrong
Symmetry and order (e.g. that things must lie in a certain way, or things must be in order)
Needing to do something until it feels right or not wrong
Here you can describe other obsessions that have not been mentioned
Hurray!
steps.text: You are finished recording your obsessions for this week. By keeping track of your obsessions and compulsions, you're taking back control, so OCD doesn't control you.

tasks.title: Symptom Hierarchy: Obsessions
tasks.description: This form is designed to help you keep track of how your obsessions change from week to week.

tasks.name: Task #7

steps.title: Compulsions
steps.text:
Symptom hierarchy: Compulsions


Compulsions are things that OCD wants you to do. If you try to resist doing these things or try not to do what OCD tells to, you may feel afraid, worried, frustrated, angry or upset.

On the next pages there will be some compulsions that many people with OCD have. Tell us how upset each compulsion (or trying to resist the compulsion) has been for you over the past week by choosing the number that best matches how you feel. 0 means that you do not have that compulsion or that does not bother you and 10 means that the compulsion upsets you so much that you can’t stand it.

steps.title: Washing or cleaning
Checking (like if you have remembered to lock the door)
Repeating actions (like turning the lights on and off several times)
Counting things
Fixing things or try to get things the same or symmetrical
Collecting things or difficulty throwing things away
Magical/superstitious behavior (e.g. doing or saying things a certain number of times to prevent something terrible from happening)
Involving others (like your parents) in a ritual or asking for reassurance
Needing to do something until it feels right
Here you can describe other compulsions that have not been mentioned
Hurray!
steps.text: You are finished recording your compulsions for this week. By keeping track of your obsessions and compulsions, you're taking back control, so OCD doesn't control you.

tasks.title: Symptom Hierarchy: Compulsions
tasks.description: This form is designed to help you keep track of how your compulsions change from week to week.

tasks.name: Task #8
tasks.title: Exposure exercise
tasks.description: Describe the exposure exercise you are working on
tasks.instructions: Describe the exposure exercise: how will you work on the obsession or compulsion?

tasks.name: Task #9
tasks.title: User Experience with the Wristband
tasks.description: Record yourself talking about how the wristband makes you feel
tasks.instructions: Tell us about your experience wearing the wristband
